title: Kim Kardashian's Brendan Dassey support 'won't help his legal case'
text:
Kim showed her support for Brendan last week (Picture: AP/Splash)

Kim Kardashian may have found her calling as a law student, but the governor watching over the case of Making A Murderer’s Brendan Dassey has insisted that the reality star’s support won’t bolster his campaign.

Dassey is currently serving a life sentence after confessing to his involvement in the 2005 murder of Teresa Halbach when he was just 16, with his case being the subject of the Netflix’s 2015 documentary series

His confession also secured the fate of Steven Avery, although both continue to protest their innocence, with Dassey’s lawyers claiming that the confession was coerced from him.

Kim’s support for the convict came after a letter was shared on social media from the now 29-year-old Brendan addressed to Governor Evans, the man presiding over his case.

Sharing Dassey’s letter, Kim wrote: ‘Please @GovEvers Read this letter.’

If there’s someone you want on your side, it’s definitely Kim K.

Dassey in 2007 (Picture: Dan Powers/AP)

However, while Kim’s high public profile and law training may seem like case-winning factors, a representative told TMZ that Governor Evers was aware of Kim’s support but: ‘Brendan’s case will be given the same thoughtful review and consideration as any other case.’

That being said, law student Kim’s support of prisoners has helped their case in the past, as she recently helped to free Alice Marie Johnson who was also facing life without parole.

After the case was a success, she then threw herself into a four-year apprenticeship with a San Francisco law firm last year – proving she’s so much more than an (exceptionally) pretty face.

Sharing her legal aspiration, Kim told US Vogue: ‘The White House called me to advise to help change the system of clemency.

‘And I’m sitting in the Roosevelt Room with, like, a judge who had sentenced criminals and a lot of really powerful people and I just sat there, like, “Oh, s**t. I need to know more.”’

She added: ‘I wanted to fight to fix it, and if I knew more, I could do more.’
